Question 1 Let \(S=\left\{ x\in \mathbb{R} \mid x= 1- \frac{1}{n}, \ n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+} \right\} \cup \left\{1 \right\}.\) (6%) Is \(S\) closed? (6%) Is it compact? (6%) Is it convex? Related Definition or Theorem Definition 1 A set \(E \in \mathbb{R}^{k}\) is convex if \[\begin{align} \lambda x + (1 - \lambda) y \in E \end{align}\] where \(x\in E, y\in E,\) and \(\lambda \in [0,1]\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:31) Definition 2 Let \(X\) be a metric space. \(E\) is bounded if there is a real number \(M\) and a point \(q\in X\) such that \(d\left( p,q \right) < M\) for all \(p\in E\). (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Definition 2.18 (i)) Theorem 1 A set \(S\) is open if and only if its complement \(S^C\) is closed. (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Theorem 2.23) Theorem 2 For any collection \(\left\{ G_\alpha \right\}\) of open sets, \(\bigcup_\alpha G_\alpha\) is open. (Rudin and others 1964, 3:34 Theorem 2.24 (i)) Theorem 3 (Heine-Borel Theorem) A set \(A \subset \mathbb{R}^n\) is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. (Marsden, Hoffman, and others 1993, 155 Theorem 3.2.1) Solution (a) We know \[\begin{align} S & = \left\{ x\in \mathbb{R} \mid x = 1 - \frac{1}{n}, n\in \mathbb{Z}^+ \right\} \cup \left\{1 \right\} \\ & = \left\{ 0, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{3}, \frac{3}{4}, \ldots, 1 \right\}. \end{align}\] (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} S^{C} & = \left( -\infty, 0 \right) \cup \left(0, \frac{1}{2} \right) \cup \left( \frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{3} \right) \cup \ldots \cup (1,\infty). \end{align}\] (2%) By Theorem 2, \(S^C\) is open. (2%) By Theorem 1, \(S\) is closed. Solution (b) (2%) Take \(r = 2\). (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} S \subset B(0, r). \end{align}\] That is, \(S\) is bounded by Definition 2. (2%) By Theorem 3, \(S\) is compact. Solution (c) (3%) Let \[\begin{align} x_1 & = 0 \in S \\ x_2 & = \frac{1}{2} \in S \\ \theta & = \frac{1}{2} \in [0,1]. \end{align}\] (3%) Then, \[\begin{align} \theta x_1 + \left( 1-\theta \right) x_2 & = \frac{1}{2}\cdot 0 + \left( 1-\frac{1}{2} \right) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \\ & = \frac{1}{4} \notin S. \end{align}\] Thus, \(S\) is not convex by Definition 1. Question 2 (8%) Consider \(f: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\). Define \[\begin{align} U_f\left( \overline{v} \right)=\{ x \mid f(x) \geq \overline{v} \} \end{align}\] where \(\overline{v} \in \mathbb{R}\). Show that \(U_f\left( \overline{v} \right)\) is a convex set for every \(\overline{v}\) if \[\begin{align} f\left( \theta x^a +(1-\theta) x^b \right) & \geq \theta f\left( x^a \right) + \left( 1-\theta \right) f\left( x^b \right) \end{align}\] for all \(x^a\) and \(x^b\) and for all \(\theta \in [0, 1]\). Solution (2%) Take \[\begin{align} x^a & \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(x^a) \geq \overline{v} \\ x^b & \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right) \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(x^b) \geq \overline{v}. \end{align}\] (2%) We get \[\begin{align} \theta f(x^a) + (1-\theta) f(x^b) & \geq \theta \overline{v} + (1-\theta) \overline{v} \\ & = \overline{v} \end{align}\] where \(\theta \in [0,1]\). (2%) Then, \[\begin{align} f\left( \theta x^a +(1-\theta) x^b \right) & \geq \theta f\left( x^a \right) + \left( 1-\theta \right) f\left( x^b \right) \\ & \geq \overline{v}. \end{align}\] (2%) Thus, \[\begin{align} \theta x^a + (1-\theta) x^b \in U_f\left( \overline{v} \right). \end{align}\] That is, \(U_f \left( \overline{v} \right)\) is a convex set for every \(\overline{v}\).

Question 4 (6%) Consider \(f: [a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), and its derivatives exist at every point in \((a, b)\) and \(f\) continuous at both end points. Assume that \(f'(x) > 0\) for all \(x \in (a, b)\). Prove that \(f(b) > f(a)\). Related Definition or Theorem Theorem 5 (Mean Value Theorem) If \(f\) is a real continuous function on \([a,b]\) which is differentiable in \((a,b)\), then there is a point \(x\in (a,b)\) at which \[\begin{align} f(b) - f(a) = f'(x) (b - a). \end{align}\] (Rudin and others 1964, 3:108 Theorem 5.10) Solution (2%) By Theorem 5, there is \(c\in (a,b)\) such that \[\begin{align} f'(c) & = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}. \end{align}\] (2%) We know \(f'(c) > 0\); \(b > a\). (2%) Thus, \[\begin{align} f(b) - f(a) > 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad f(b) > f(a). \end{align}\] References

Question 5 Consider a function \(f: \mathbb{R}^3 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) as follows. \[\begin{align} f(x_1,x_2, x_3)= \begin{cases} \frac{x_1 x_2 + x_3 ^2 }{x_1^2+x_2^2+2x_3^2}, & \quad \mbox{if } (x_1,x_2, x_3) \neq (1,1, 1) \\ 0, & \quad \mbox{if } (x_1,x_2, x_3) =(1,1,1). \end{cases} \end{align}\] (6%) Show that \(f\) is not continuous at \((1,1,1)\). (6%) Show that \(\frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2, x_3)}{\partial x_3}\) does not exist at \((1, 1, 1)\). Solution (a) (2%) Consider a sequence \(\{x_n\}\) with \[\begin{align} x_{in} = 1 + \frac{1}{n} \end{align}\] where \(x_n = (x_{1n}, x_{2n}, x_{3n})\) and \(i=1,2,3\). (2%) We know \[\begin{align} x_n \rightarrow (1,1,1) \end{align}\] as \(n \rightarrow \infty\). (2%) We find \[\begin{align} \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} f(x_n) & = \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} \frac{2\left( 1+\frac{1}{n} \right)^2}{4\left( 1+\frac{1}{n} \right)^2} = \frac{1}{2} \\ & \neq f(1,1,1) = 0. \end{align}\] Thus, \(f\) is not continuous at \((1,1,1)\). Solution (b) (6%) We find \[\begin{align} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_3}(1,1,1) & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{f(1,1,1+h) - f(1,1,1)}{h} \\ & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{1+(1+h)^2}{1+1+2(1+h)^2} - 0}{h} \\ & = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2h} = \infty. \end{align}\] Thus, \(\frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2, x_3)}{\partial x_3}\) does not exist at \((1, 1, 1)\).
